content.raw:
> The intent is to move the capabilities of https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_openni_kinect.cpp from a ROS plugin directly into simulation.

If you're looking at the Kinetic version of the plugin, you may be interested in [this pull request](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/pull/757) which suggests a more updated approach.
content.html:
The intent is to move the capabilities of https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/src/gazebo_ros_openni_kinect.cpp from a ROS plugin directly into simulation.

If you're looking at the Kinetic version of the plugin, you may be interested in this pull request which suggests a more updated approach.

content.raw: The ign-rendering [documentation](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/src/7248ad060b060ae4ae53b19f61ed9516a91f8ef3/include/ignition/rendering/Camera.hh#lines-157) is a bit confusing, but I think it's not recommended to use `Capture` if there's more than one camera in the scene, because we'd be making redundant render calls. I don't think we need to change this now, but just thought I'd mention it.
content.html: The ign-rendering documentation is a bit confusing, but I think it's not recommended to use Capture if there's more than one camera in the scene, because we'd be making redundant render calls. I don't think we need to change this now, but just thought I'd mention it.

content.raw: Can you add a `todo` for this please?
content.html: Can you add a todo for this please?
6b69e04

content.raw: should we also set the NearClipPlane on the depthCamera?
content.html: should we also set the NearClipPlane on the depthCamera?

content.raw: The `DepthCameraSensor` didn't set the near clip, and I copied the code from that sensor. There might be a reason to not set the near clip. Or, both sensors could be in error.
content.html: The DepthCameraSensor didn't set the near clip, and I copied the code from that sensor. There might be a reason to not set the near clip. Or, both sensors could be in error.

content.raw: Shouldn't we use the same clipping distances for both cameras, since this is essentially a single sensor?
content.html: Shouldn't we use the same clipping distances for both cameras, since this is essentially a single sensor?

content.raw: I don't know. Give it a try. I operated on the assumption that the DepthCameraSensor is correct, which doesn't set the near clip plane.
content.html: I don't know. Give it a try. I operated on the assumption that the DepthCameraSensor is correct, which doesn't set the near clip plane.

content.raw: Ok, using the same clipping for both cameras, nothing seems to be out of place: 3a7e8ca
content.html: Ok, using the same clipping for both cameras, nothing seems to be out of place: 3a7e8ca

content.raw: I don't think we should use the same clipping distances. The clipping for depth is based on the depth sensor, which is often less than 10 meters, while the clipping for RGB is often much larger
content.html: I don't think we should use the same clipping distances. The clipping for depth is based on the depth sensor, which is often less than 10 meters, while the clipping for RGB is often much larger

content.raw: some example parameters in this tutorial: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/531/update-depth-camera-descriptions/diff
content.html: some example parameters in this tutorial: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/531/update-depth-camera-descriptions/diff

content.raw:
Ok, that makes sense. At the moment we don't have a good way of specifying the depth clipping distances through SDF though, so we were using hardcoded values. Do you prefer hardcoding or copying the camera clipping?

I'd also point out that even though the camera image may see beyond the point cloud, those pixels won't have any points to color. So it's useful if someone is subscribing just to the RGB image, but not useful for anyone using the combined RGBD data.
content.html:
Ok, that makes sense. At the moment we don't have a good way of specifying the depth clipping distances through SDF though, so we were using hardcoded values. Do you prefer hardcoding or copying the camera clipping?

I'd also point out that even though the camera image may see beyond the point cloud, those pixels won't have any points to color. So it's useful if someone is subscribing just to the RGB image, but not useful for anyone using the combined RGBD data.

content.raw:
I guess we should copy the camera clipping for now with a note to add an sdf parameter. That's better than hard-coding. I think the sdf parameter could look something like the following:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/commits/e09a283ad42bd910f70f52879ea0c03c8c11a7e0
content.html:
I guess we should copy the camera clipping for now with a note to add an sdf parameter. That's better than hard-coding. I think the sdf parameter could look something like the following:

https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/commits/e09a283ad42bd910f70f52879ea0c03c8c11a7e0

content.raw: Note that the DepthCamera in ign-rendering supports up to PI\*2 but the max hfov a normal rgb camera can do is 90 degrees
content.html: Note that the DepthCamera in ign-rendering supports up to PI*2 but the max hfov a normal rgb camera can do is 90 degrees

content.raw: it may still work if >90 degrees is specified but based on the [ogre documentat](https://www.ogre3d.org/docs/api/1.9/class_ogre_1_1_frustum.html#aa6f83f76980139d6a9c36abf635e0c75)ion the view will be distorted so I'm not sure if the `rgb` pixels will align with the `d` pixels. Something to verify in the future.
content.html: it may still work if >90 degrees is specified but based on the ogre documentation the view will be distorted so I'm not sure if the rgb pixels will align with the d pixels. Something to verify in the future.
